title: 109_hr5361
content: The Act may be cited as the "Platform Equality and Remedies for Rights Holders in Music Act of 2006" or the "Perform Act of 2006". Rate setting standards are established. The "Platform Equality and Remedies for Rights Holders in Music Act of 2006" or the "Perform Act of 2006" establishes rate setting standards for licenses under sections 112 and 114 of title 17, United States Code. Amendments are made to determine fair market value and royalty payments for eligible transmissions. The "Perform Act of 2006" sets rate setting standards for licenses under sections 112 and 114 of title 17, US Code. Amendments determine fair market value and royalty payments for eligible transmissions every 5 years. The "Perform Act of 2006" amends rate setting standards for licenses under sections 112 and 114 of title 17, US Code to determine fair market value and royalty payments for eligible transmissions every 5 years. Amendments include changes to the language in the third and fourth sentences. The "Perform Act of 2006" updates rate setting standards for licenses under sections 112 and 114 of title 17, US Code every 5 years. Amendments include adjustments to language regarding fair market value and royalty payments for eligible transmissions. The "Perform Act of 2006" updates rate setting standards for licenses every 5 years, including determining reasonable terms and rates of royalty payments for new types of services on which sound recordings are performed. In chapter 8, the parties may agree on the expiration period. The term 'eligible transmission' includes various types of transmissions. Section 114(d)(2) of title 17, United States Code, is amended for content protection. The text discusses amendments to section 114(d)(2) of title 17, United States Code, regarding content protection for eligible transmissions. It involves adding clauses and removing others to address the making of copies or phonorecords during transmission. The amendments to section 114(d)(2) of title 17, United States Code involve redesignating clauses and adding a provision stating that offering a transmission and metadata does not enable copying. Performing rights societies can monitor public performances of copyrighted works in transmissions and be granted a license for retransmission at a minimal cost. The amendment to section 114(j) of title 17, United States Code defines "reasonable recording" as making a copy of a performance for private, noncommercial use under a license. The amendment to section 114(j) of title 17, United States Code allows for private, noncommercial use of recordings with specific technological measures in place. These measures include automated recording or playback based on user-selected programs, time periods, or channels, while prohibiting automated playback based on specific sound recordings, albums, or artists. Additionally, the measures prevent the separation of copyrighted material segments and the redistribution or retransmission of recorded performances. The amendment to section 114(j) of title 17, United States Code allows for private, noncommercial use of recordings with specific technological measures in place. This includes restrictions on digital outputs or removable media unless part of a secure in-home network complying with the paragraph. Non-automated manual recording and playback are permitted without infringing copyright. Technical and conforming amendments are made to section 114(f) of title 17, United States Code. Amendments are made to various sections of title 17, United States Code, including changes to sections 801, 803, and 804. These changes involve striking and inserting specific references within the paragraphs. Amendments to title 17, United States Code involve striking specific references in clauses (i) and (iv) of certain sections. The Register of Copyrights will convene a meeting within 60 days of a final determination by the Copyright Royalty Judges to discuss creating a new category of limited interactive services. A report on the meeting will be submitted to the Senate and House Judiciary Committees within 90 days.
